Executive Summary

The Niagara County Water District Williams Road Treatment Plant provides potable water for 150,000 people in Towns and Villages located in Niagara, Erie and Orleans Counties.  The treatment plant utilizes pre-chlorination, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation and filtration processes to ensure the quality of the water.  


The Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled 

Introduction

The Niagara County Water District operates a 32 MGD Water Treatment Plant that uses chlorination for disinfection and zebra muscle control.  Chlorine (Cl2) is a regulated substance that is used in the water treatment process and stored at the treatment plant.  There are eight, 1 ton tanks used for the storage of chlorine.  The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored at the treatment plant is therefore 16,000 pounds.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Niagara County Water District (NCWD) periodically conducts hazard reviews to identify, evaluate and control the risk associated with the process hazards and chemical release scenarios at the NCWD Williams Road Water Treatment Plant.  The overall purpose of the hazard review is to prevent or minimize the effects of a chemical release and to comply with EPA regulations. Whenever necessary, recommendations are made during the review to reduce the risk associated with a hazard or release scenario to an acceptable level.  

At the NCWD or any other water treatment plant, well-trained operators are integral to preventing and mitigating the effects of accidental chemical releases.  The NCWD provides an employee-training program for all Cl2 operators and maintenance personnel and employees participate in an annual evacuation drill.  Personnel and contractors working at the regulated facility receive emergency response awareness-level training.  In addition, selected Cl2 operators and maintenance personnel receive responder-level training.


General Accidental Release Prevention Pr

ogram

The Niagara County Water District has a mechanical integrity program.  The purpose of the mechanical integrity program is to ensure the continued integrity of the process equipment.  An effective mechanical integrity program is integral to preventing accidental chemical releases that may result from mechanical failure of improperly maintained equipment.  The mechanical integrity program includes the following elements:
? Identification of critical equipment and instrumentation.
? Written maintenance, testing and inspection schedules and procedures.
? Maintenance personnel training.
? Maintenance, testing, and inspection completion and documentation.
? Correction of equipment deficiencies.
? Quality assurance of new equipment.

All incidents at the NCWD Williams Road Plant which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a release of chlorine, will be promptly investigated.  The purpose of the incident investigation procedure is to identify the underlying causes of an incident and to implement corrective actions to prevent the incident from reoccurring. 

Five Year Accident History
 
The Niagara County Water District has had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.


Emergency Response Program

The Niagara County Water District has an Emergency Response Program in place to be prepared for any accidental releases of chlorine.  The chlorine feed room is continuously monitored by chlorine gas sensors which will activate an alarm system if the ambient chlorine gas levels reach 3-5 ppm.  The Chief Operator and/or Plant Maintenance Supervisor is responsible for the overall emergency coordination.  In the absence of the Chief Operator, or Plant Maintenance Supervisor, the Operator in Charge shall assume emergency coordinator responsibilities.  Responsibilities include: 
a) Notification of the Plant Supervisor and the County Water Superintendent as required.
b) Notification of the fire department and law enforcement : 911
c) Coordinating and c

ooperating with town, county state and federal emergency and regulatory agencies and officials.
d) The following agencies must be notified when there has been a release of 10 lbs. or greater of chlorine into air or water, or 4.54 lbs. or greater of chlorine onto the land.
i) Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)
ii) New York State Emergency Response Center
iii) National Response Center

 
Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The NCWD conducted a Process Hazard Analysis on May 25, 2004.  No process changes were identified to improve safety.  One planned administrative/procedural change was identified.  The procedural change was for the development of an operating protocol for handling of chlorine cylinders at remote pump stations that are under the amount regulated by the MRP program requirements.
